answers.answer: The top 5 nutrients listed as essential for thyroid function are iodine, selenium, zinc, vitamin D, vitamin E.  Vitamin D council recommend 25(OH) D levels between 125 - 200nmol/L year round.  200mcg of selenium daily is shown in a number of human clinical trials to lower TPOAb.  Anecdotally, a gluten free diet lowers TgAb.Glucose between 100 to 125 mg/dL is a diagnosis of pre diabetes. Magnesium is necessary for both the action of insulin and the manufacture of insulin and a deficiency is linked to insulin resistance, pre diabetes and diabetes.  Only 0.3% of magnesium is in blood serum so at a cellular level you could be very deficient.  Magnesium is also the most important co factor for vitamin D absorption and all the major minerals (calcium, potassium, sodium) are dependent on magnesium being present in order to function.Low or deficient vitamin A is noted in hypothyroidism due to the slowing down of beta carotene to vitamin A conversion. As your thyroid is overactive, having good levels of vitamin A is not surprising. If vitamin A levels get too high, symptoms can include skin discolouration, excessive skin dryness/peeling, intracranial pressure, and hair loss.Lab ranges vary but a normal HDL range can be from 40 up to 86 mg/dL and LDL from 80 up to 130 mg/dL so your cholesterol is fine.  Manganese is an unusual test for the doctor to request however it is in range.

question: Hello,Here is another question. I have gotten a complete blood screening  and wanted to know if any of the below influences the production of thyroid antibodies (either TPOAb or TSHRAb) and/or the thyroid function itself, particularly the overactive one:++ Marginally HIGH values:Glucose: 110 (range 76 - 110 mg/dL)Vitamin A: 800 (range 300 - 800)-- Marginally LOW values:Sodium: 136 (137 - 145 mmol/l)Magnesium: 0.72  (.72 - 1.25 mMol/L)-- InsufficiencyVitamin D 25-OH: 56 (Insufficiency level 25 - 75 nmol/L)++ HIghManganese: 2    (range 1-2)HDL Cholesterol:  75 (range 45 - 65) <- this is suppose to be goodLDL Cholesterol:  95  (range, it didn't come)
title: Minerals, Vitamins and Thyroid Disorders
